Title: Toxic Culture
View8: Fidelity is well known for their great benefits. Although their salaries tend to be way below what other companies pay. It's a great place to start, get your certifications, and then go somewhere else where they'll double your pay. This is what most engineers were doing at the time I was there. After I left, I doubled my salary at another firm.
View10:
I worked at Fidelity from 2018-2019 and found it to be one of the most toxic cultures I’ve ever experienced in my 20+ years as a professional. 
I worked in ECC where, although being a highly technical BU, the Sr leadership (at the time), promoted several non-technical people into leadership positions. I worked under one of these, a woman (HJ) who had a knack for hiring and promoting underqualified people, thereby creating a situation where they needed to be “protected” and would be loyal to her. This included promoting an individual from QA to a PM role with zero experience, as well as someone from the event planning dept to a Dir level leading a UX team. 
The situation was so wily, that at one point, this PM (LV) held several meetings to explain to our highly experienced UX team “UX Strategy”. She’d done her research on Google. I wish I was joking. Later, she would hold “UX Strategy” meetings that only included the one UX designer and a young woman whose role was designing PP decks for leadership (SJ). She insisted on defining herself as the UX Researcher, even though (you guessed it) she had no experience doing research and never actually conducted any research. But she was really good at gossiping, slandering, and keeping VP abreast of BU gossip.  I wish I was joking. These people were not only unqualified and unprofessional, they were MEAN.
The PM for this team created a corrosive and toxic environment; she battled constantly with the PO in front of the full 20+ team, deliberately excluded key players from meetings, showed open aggression in smaller meetings, bullied several individuals, and was just a hostile aggressive person in general.
There was another individual promoted by this VP who not only lacked in technical or leadership skills, but was one of the most badly behaved individuals of the entire team (MVH). She led a team of several people and had the emotional IQ of a 13 YO girl. She also bullied members of her own team, behaved in a hostile manner, openly threated team members, and acted appallingly. When new leadership came in and there was a reorg, she kept her position but lost her entire team. That should tell you all you need to know about Fidelity. The fact that all these people are still employed there is insane.
And make no mistake, the behavior of this group of women was endorsed by their own leadership (HJ). They knew they could get away with it and they did. Tactics included: mobbing, bullying individuals and teams, open aggression in meetings, withholding vital information, excluding individuals from specific team meetings, openly threatening individuals, slandering those who refused to play their game, and even firing those who refused to fall in line or pushed back.
Many associates complained to both HR and the Chairman’s line about this group of women, but the only sense we had that they were taking any actions was when HR executives showed up to an offsite event. But you guessed it, nothing happened. HR exists only to protect the firm. If there are no lawsuits possible, they don’t care.
This “leader” is now a VP in PI and continues her abusive, toxic behavior, as well as promoting only those who show their loyalty to her, as evidenced by the woman she just promoted to Director. In fact, all these women still hold positions at Fidelity. They may be scattered across the enterprise, but it’s just a matter of time until VP brings them all back onto her team and it all begins again.

Title: Changing for the worse
View8:
Benefits
Remote work
Great place to start your career. Get out and get paid more after.
View10: Have worked here for 6 years in 3 different locations. Management has gotten worse. I used to think “Wow. The management really cares about advancing my career and helping me” that tune has changed. It’s become a corporate boys club and full of toxic negativity. You have to leave the firm and come back to get any type of promotion or pay increase. They don’t hire from within they literally have jobs that say external hire only. What kind of garbage is that? It’s a boys club so if you’re a female in this finance world, good luck. Management is fake and can’t be real with their employees like they used to. They have to drink the corporate Kool-aid and give everyone corporate BS answers. Fidelity has started to care so much about money that the client experience is going to the way side. I used to love how client oriented we were. They are changing everything to be about money and how do we make the most money and work the employees the hardest.

Title: A great company
View8: - Benefits are excellent. - Very stable and low pressure job. - Upper management genuinely seems to care. Employees frequently receive pulse surveys and then Fidelity will share the results from the surveys publicly, blemishes and all. You will actually see management try to make changes to fix the weak spots. - A lot of focus on learning and development. 4 hours every two weeks is left open for any trainings, lessons, or experiments you are interested in doing.
View10: - The base pay is lower than the market, making you reliant on your end of year bonus to bring it in line. - Raises are low unless they come attached with a promotion. - People tend to work at Fidelity for a very long time, which makes it difficult for new talent and ideas to come in and mix things up. - Fidelity loves to pretend its a tech company, but does not have the technical talent to back it up. This causes there to be a lot of "flashy" things like containers and microservices, but not a lot of talent to utilize them fully which can make things worse than traditional architectures.

Title: It's a great place to work, and work you will
View8:
Benefits, Benefits, Benefits - across the board best company to work for regarding benefits. (401(k) +matching, profit sharing, bonuses, etc.)
The company has a real culture that makes you truly feel part of the company.
Good focus on inclusion and overall work environment.
They care about the success and retention of their employees
Career growth opportunities
View10:
Work/Life balance can be tough with a high pace and even higher expectations
Big company with a big hierarchy
Success is overly dependent on intracompany relationships often grounded with tenure in the company
While extending your career and experience is highly encouraged, transitions and upward mobility can be challenging.

Title: Loves the company, not so much the job

Title: Fantastic company to work for!

Title: Great company, great benefits
View8: Benefits, culture, people, opportunities, compensation package

Title: Great Management

Title: Why didn't you refer this plan participant to a nearby Fidelity Investor Center?
View8: Financial planning tools are effective, if you slip up and actually provide real financial planning to the plan participant. Less than all of the participants are rude and ignorant. You'll always be able to ply your craft because there is always a queue of participants to speak to. The Fidelity RSP 401k match is strong and, coupled with 10 percent profit sharing, makes it very easy to save a lot of money for retirement. So you'll only be poor during your career and not also in a long retirement.
View10: Fidelity wants Workplace Planning and Advice and its Workplace Planning Consultants to refer opportunities to the Investor Center. That's the job. Say whatever you need to get the referral and you'll advance in your career. Any personal ethos of Do what's Right will be compromised in WPA. The answer to everything, everything, is refer the opportunity to the Investor Center. Also there is no way that compensation for Fidelity phone roles is materially-higher than any industry average.

Title: Plenty of room to grow
View8: Amazing benefits. The company even added extra benefits to support employees through the Covid pandemic. The enterprise is so large that after 22 years, I still have options to learn and grow without boredom.
View10: Some managers are just not good at their job and it feels like there’s nothing an associate can do about it.

Title: Good company with good people
View8: The benefits are good, the people are nice, and the company does try hard to take care of the employees. 7% 401k match dollar for dollar and full health care coverage on day one. 25 days of PTO for first year employees.
View10: A lot of people working from home so it is hard to get to know your coworkers. A lot of time on the phones, but I would say 95% of the clients are nice. You have to pass your Series 7 & 63 pretty quick, they let go a few coworkers for not passing on the first try.

Title: Good experience
View8: 23 days PTO, everyone wants to get you promoted, 4x10 shifts. Good learning experience. Company with good reputation makes sales roles less salesy and more about helping out clients.
View10: Repetitive, new hires work weekends or late night

Title: Fixed income
View8: retirement contributions is a nice benefit
View10: care about new hires more then tenured employees for raises. New managers are hit or miss with being power hungry and micro managing you. Been here 3 years and have had 8 different managers

Title: Company review
View8:
-great work/life balance
-good company culture

View10:
- no cons that I can think of rn

Title: Fidelity
View8: Healthy benefits and pay profit sharing
View10: Management will micromanage and push

Title: Loveit
View8: Great company, benefits, team culture

Title: Wonderful Company--Not a great manager

Instead of any sort of follow up or proactive reach out to me with warning, I was immediately fired with no questions. I loved this company and I loved my job, and I was good at it. I hate that one month cost me my entire career, and my manager did not try to reach out at all.

Title: Job fell short of what it was advertised as
View8: They spare no expense in getting you set up with at home equipment and IT assistance

That could be questions over materials or a overall company required training (2 hours) and when I took that, I was reprimanded that I was 'milking company time' since i wasn't in the training material. After I left, others had shared similar experiences and they changed the required company HR trainings to 1 hour max.

Title: Great company!

Decent pay with the opportunity for many bonuses through the year. Great training with the opportunity to earn you Series 7/63 licenses.
View10: Licensing can be difficult, but manageable if you’re willing to put the work in.

Title: Great Place To Work So Far
View8: Working fully remote from home as an Investment Solutions Representative. Enjoy the no work commute which means more time to spend with my family. Great benefits.

Title: 20+ years at this great company!

We have a leader that cares about her (female owned, private company!) employees as well as the bottom line. During COVID, we were one of the first companies to go fully remote in order to keep everyone safe and healthy. I cannot say enough good things about Fidelity, and my tenure at the firm proves that!

Title: Good benefits

Where company contributes cash you can access as a retiree for medical expenses. I took the early retirement incentive and left
View10: Sometimes shifts from focussing on their goal of helping our clients become better investors toward helping the company increase AUM to get a bonus ad/for so my friends do t get laid off.

Title: Fidelity
View8: Compensation, potential long term advancement

Title: Felt Like I Was On A Treadmill
View8: Benefits were above average and communication was usually clear.
View10: Most days were spent working overtime just to stay on top of things and overtime was always expected/asked. Working six days a week of at least 9-10 hours a day was the norm. Constantly felt understaffed and most days felt like drowning. Help by management was always promised on the horizon, but after being told that for two years, it was clear nothing was being done. Requesting time off around the Holidays like Christmas was done by a lottery system and, because of that, I missed Christmas with my family for three straight years. I have friends working at Charles Schwab and TD and they have shared their experience was nothing like that.

Title: Good starting point

Title: Fidelity
View8: Benefits, work life balance, work from home
View10: Pay is lower than other firms Rich in benefits but cheap in salary potential Metric focused - pushed hard

Title: Call Center work
View8: Decent pay, ability to work from home.
View10: Still a call center job at it's core with unrealistic measurements for associate performance. Bonus pay also unfairly measured. Management is only in contact with you for reconstructive criticism and not usually available for customers that request to speak to a manager, for that you are on your own as an associate, and that usually affects the customer feedback that affects your bonus. Overall just another call center job.

Title: Lots of bureaucracy and need to be willing to brown-nose to get ahead
View8:
Good pay & benefits
Stable company
Does provide a valuable service

Very bureaucratic - lots of layers
Hard to get noticed and job roles/responsibilities are often ambiguous
Leadership is not a strength - people so busy trying to step over people to get ahead that they forget to provide oversight and direction

Title: Strong Community, Weak Pay
View8:
- Strong community
-Good job security
- They hire from within before outside, and there are always opportunities to move laterally. Which is encouraged every 3-5 years or so. 
- Many employee resource groups and support programs. 
- lots of networking opportunities. 
- If you want to gain a certain skill or a certain license, management is usually pretty good at finding a way to let you grow skills, even if that means you will leave your current team. Again, they are big on lateral moves.
- A much more relaxed environment compared to other high-stress brokerage firms.
View10:
- Depending on your position you can be working very long hours. ( Ie Tax season or "giving season" will have you working 8 am-8 pm)
- The pay is lower compared to other brokerage firms. 
- Pay is dependent on seniority, not ability. It's incredibly frustrating to be a top performer in a team, but know you make significantly less than a senior team member, who does not perform well. ( you will get raises but you won't be lifted up to the pay level of a person who has been there for 20 years and has grown complacent) The best way to get raises quickly is through lateral movement and negoation. 
- It is very difficult to get a management position, simply because the company is so big, there is always a large pool of applicants to compete against. 
- Many times when people leave, instead of hiring a new person, they pile that job on an existing team member, but will not raise that team member's pay. Just the expectations. 
- The quality of your manager makes a big difference in your experience. Sadly good managers get promoted and move on to better things, and then a novice is sent to replace them. Great for the managers, bad for the senior team members.

Title: Great for entry level, not if you have actual experience
View8: If you’re getting into the industry and can’t find anyone to hire you this is a great place to start. They at least offer benefits and a salary. The sales training is good and you’ll be exposed to HNW and UHNW clients to take with you when you leave in 2-3 years.
View10: Constant micromanagement around numbers. Calls, appointments, plans, sales pitches, etc.  They say that you are running your own practice but watch every move you make and tell you how to interact with customers.  When I tell other actual advisors what Fidelity does they think it’s criminal, they’re selling cheeseburgers and calling it steak. They want to be the largest RIA in the country but this isn’t it.  The investment management arm of the company (Strategic Advisors) is the RIA. This job is trying to use their watered down planning software to convince customers to buy managed products.  FCs are encouraged (read: compensated) to send the relationship to strategic advisors when it’s closed. This is nothing like a real RIA, trust me I’ve worked at two boutiques. Look no further than the WAS program, where FCs refer clients to actual financial advisors and boutiques. The longest tenured FC in my office was about 3-4 years. Some advice for job seekers, this should be your last option, try to get on with a real RIA first.

Title: Decent
View8: Great benefits, decent pay, work/life balance
View10: Too much emphasis on hiring managers with soft skills, not enough emphasis on hiring management/leadership with actual experience in the department they're managing.

Title: Stuck on Java
View8:
* More than enough PTO (23 days + 5 days covid/family relief time)
* Deadlines are reasonable for epics and sprints, low stress to get work done on time
* Pay is pretty good for RDU metro area
View10:
* Stuck on Java as the primary language. Reasoning for that is legacy code integrates more easily, and they know they can hire for Java. But recent graduates like myself probably don't like using it as much as Python, Go, etc.
* Slow to lay out concrete details for return to office

Title: Good place to start
View8: It’s a healthy work life balance culture and a great place to get a start in the industry
View10: You can get an increase in pay and job quickly but you do hit a ceiling at a certain point

Title: Great job, potential burn out
View8: Great training, benefits, and overall support
View10: Metrics based doesn't work for everyone - if you can hit your goals you'll get promoted, but if you can't meet your goals you might get burnt out

Title: Call Center
View8: Great support amongst higher-ups Many opportunities with enough networking and effort
View10: No cons, the job was simply not for me

Title: It’s all about the metrics
View8: Nice people, good training, good benefits
View10: No matter how much they romanticize making a connection with clients, what truly matters in this role always comes back to metrics. If they can’t measure it, it doesn’t count, and you’re only as good as your metrics say. It’s relentless and offers little autonomy and a ton of scrutiny and micromanagement. If that’s not your thing, this isn’t your place.

Title: Very stressful
View8: They train you Health insurance starts day one
View10: The management hovers over you Micromanaged to the point they might as well take the call themselves Cared more about numbers of call than the quality of the call They time your lunch break and bathroom breaks to the minute and ‘ding’ you if you are a minute off the phones Staff are nervous to even go to the bathroom when needed!

Title: WPC
View8:
- Decent pay
- Good benefits (very long vesting schedule for some)
- Pay for training/licensing, although Fidelity does have a big problem of reps leaving after being paid to obtain the licenses
- They are currently promoting reps very quickly through the WPA department
View10:
- Taking phone calls all day long (the majority I had would message you within 5 minutes of not being on the phone, but that could help obviously vary with locations/managers)

- Very high turnover. My team had 5 different managers within 6 months. Reps also leave very quickly to get off the phones. The company really has a plan in place to make their reps stay in the call center as long as possible. Bonus payments are structured to make you feel like it is just close enough to stay for a little while longer. Also a year requirement of work after you obtain your licenses before you can move to a branch role (which are very competitive, and typically are outside hires anyways)

- Extremely sales oriented, but a lot of the clients think we are service. Be prepared for awkward calls where you and the client have completely separate agendas. Instead of servicing the clients need and moving on to help the next, the company would rather you run them through their retirement tools. These tools can be beneficial in some instances, but they are extremely general and many of these clients have recognized that they don’t help much. Seems the department is only here to promote these tools. Only goal on every single call is to take the clients need, acknowledge it while basically ignoring it, run them through the retirement tools so we can gather outside assets, and then set an appointment with a branch so they can move those to Fidelity.

I understand there are plenty of roles similar to this, the only difference is that a lot of the hiring managers at Fidelity do not warn you of this. Multiple reps on my team and I had this same experience.

Overall, this role and the constant phone calls will exhaust you. I would recommend looking elsewhere first if your goal is to get into financial advising. If necessary, this can be a decent role in the short-term.

Title: Awesome company!!
View8: I’ve been here for almost a year and waited until I had “seen it all” to post a review. Fidelity really cares for their employees, what they say is VERY true. We get bonuses on top of bonuses just by working and doing what we’re supposed to be doing. Amazing PTOs about 23 days for all associates that have been here for less than 2 years. Amazing health, dental, vision etc etc the standard basic benefits but what really got me was how much they invest in you as an associate. I’m truly blessed to work for such a great organization!
View10: Micromanaging can be a problem however, as to be expected if you are on a phone role. May feel like you are “stuck” and stagnant at a role but in the mean time I am seeing lots of employment opportunities to move around. It may take a bit longer for you to move around and the pay may be below average for the same job elsewhere but the benefits package are for sure to be top notch all around.

Title: As advertised
View8: good management, PTO and benefits available right when you start. Work culture is good and most clients on the phone are easy to handle. If you already have a finance background this is a easy step into the field and can net you a life long job within the company.
View10: Expect to be tested on Series 7/63 within 3 months of starting role. This isn't a permanent position until you pass these exams and failure means losing your job.

Title: Amazing Company, Pay Tradeoff
View8: Fidelity has amazing benefits, is seriously one of the best companies to work for in terms of work/life balance. You manager actually push you to move up in the company and want you to succeed.
View10:
You trade extra PTO and an amazing company culture for a little less pay than the rest of the industry and the sales roles don't really have commission. 
If all you care about is money maybe not the right place, but if you want somewhere you can grow and enjoy your life APPLY!

Title: Fast paced, great career experience but watch for management issues
View8: Holistic Retirement and Investment Planning and Guidance, access to specialists, industry leader in tech utilization. You will get top notch experience here. Incredibly high level efficiency. Other advisors and specialists are overall great people with team-oriented mentality.
View10: Pay, high stress level, work hours can easily spill into the evening, very high level of expectation including weekly meetings, planning interactions and proposals (more than double most other places). Management may also make assurances and not follow through or even backtrack. Without other specifics, HR and Management were competent overall but among the worst I've ever worked with and I will not say why here. If the company allows or endorses this management type I would stay clear.

Title: Great Company
View8: Employer benefits, bonuses, support for licensing
View10: Bonuses come several times a year but the hourly rate could be better.

Title: Great Company
View8: Good benefits, culture, and upward mobility
View10: Salaries are lower than other companies Not many opportunities for full time remote working

Title: Not good for original thinkers

Title: Good WLB and Nice People

Title: Fidelity Will Ruin Your IT Career With a Smile
View8: The benefits package is above average.
View10:
Fidelity will destroy an IT carrier.  

They will work you to death on out date tech that won't do you any good outside their doors.  

Manager's are immune to repercussions for their actions. While employees are expected to follow very high standards of conduct.  Discrimination of all forms is common and well accepted by HR.

If you are going to work for Fidelity make sure you fall into a category of person your manager likes, or they will destroy you with the full support of the HR department. 

You also better make sure you don't have kids to take care of, or turn 40.  I worked there for a decade and no one ever retired by choice.

Title: Great place to work

Title: Great place to work
View8: Benefits are second to none

Title: 5 Stars for a reason

Title: Nice People. Behind in Technology

Title: Excellent Company to Work For

Title: Great culture and benefits
View8: - Work life balance - Benefits - Work from home flexibility

Title: Best in the biz (its the biz thats the problem)
View8: Great benefits, good pay and great culture. Although limited and flawed at times the company does care and tries to help every associate succeed. Also a lot of upward and sideways mobility, if you work hard the world is your oyster. Also you gain SO MUCH important knowledge about economics and the stock market that you can use in everyday life.
View10:
Internal systems are a nightmare, its a Frankenstein mishmash of all these old in house systems that don't play nice together and are not very user friendly. Also training is rushed adding an un-needed degree of pressure to new hires already working a difficult job.

 And the job no matter how good everything else could be is a tough tough job. It takes at least a year to get any good but once you pass your "trial by fire" and give it 100% this can be a very rewarding career especially for someone like me with no college degree.

Title: Smoke and Mirrors

Title: Not worth it

Title: Best place I've ever worked
View8: Benefits, pay, schedule, culture, management are head and shoulders above any other financial firm I have worked for in the past. The job is incredibly reasonable and the pay is significantly above competition. If you can get a job offer from fidelity and you are working for another BD just take it. Upward mobility is real and they push it. If you are happy in your role you can stay in it without absurd changes in metrics. The company is solely customer centric so if you make a suggestion that makes the life of the client better that comes before profits.

Title: Great Environment, Demanding Work
View8: - Very accommodating staff, great onboarding process - Fidelity is dedicated to teaching you the basics and provides comprehensive training - Management and the people I worked under always made themselves available to me at my convenience. I'd even say they were some of the best people I have worked for.
View10:
- As a CRA my entire job was answering a nonstop stream of phone calls
- While the training program is nice, you will NEVER fully be trained or prepared for what calls you may receive. 
- There is a massive variety of calls you may receive, which can leave you juggling a client, researching a solution and reaching out to other departments to find a solution.
- Once training was done I was put onto a new work schedule that ruined my work/life balance. I tried for multiple months to get a new schedule but since I was a newer employee I was never able to get something a bit more accomodating.

Title: Racist place. Only interviews minorities to meet Quota.

View10: If you don't look like one of them you'll never get hired. There needs to be an internal investigation in Fidelity to see what their interview/hiring process is regarding minorities. After multiple phone interviews they seemed to be ready to move forward with me until they met with me in person and saw I didn't look like them. I could tell by their face they didn't expect me to be a person of color. I knocked the interview out of the park despite their obvious discomfort. Later found out they didn't want to move forward with me. Something tells me there will be a class action lawsuit coming soon in that firm.

Title: High stress
View8: Good pay and benefits are provided.
View10: Almost every metric imaginable is tracked. This is an extremely stressful work environment with no down time. The extra money I receive from this company is offset by medical expenses to manage my anxiety and depression I’ve developed since working here. You will be continually told that relief is coming in the form of more employees, but for three years this has yet to happen to counteract turnover. If you want to take 6-8 phone calls an hour, be insulted daily by clients, work mandatory overtime, and develop crippling mental health issues, this is the company for you.

Title: Very Corporate
View8:
Work life balance
Pay/benefits 
Paid time off
Great 401k match and profit sharing 
Decent resources for training and development
View10:
Can be substantial micro management from the branch leaders in the investor centers. 

Investor centers always seem to be understaffed creating a strain on other roles. High turnover. 

Substantial concentration on metrics that drive your performance bonus with no consideration that some roles get wrapped up in service when their role responsibility doesn’t not include service and their main metrics don’t credit any service work.

No real autonomy to follow your own planning process. Their process is all by their book which can sometimes feel non genuine when working with clients.

Title: Unrelenting Work Environment
View8: Many very talented colleagues and depending on where you work you get to do very interesting work. Internal information and learning resources are great.
View10: A ceaseless grind. Nervous, risk-averse, fear driven work environment. Restructuring and layoffs were constant. Success is entirely in the hands of your direct manager, so while it depends on who your manager is, largely the culture reinforces doing what the boss says and being very cautious about expressing any alternate perspectives. Many people have been there for years and the inside club can be defensive of their turf. You are encouraged to not think of compensation and instead the 'total value' of the package, but never-the-less, I found overall pay to be below market.

Title: Management only cares about metrics and fails to look at bigger picture.
View8: -401k match -Tuition reimbursement -decent work-life balance -trauma bonds built with coworkers forged friendships that will last a lifetime
View10:
-Very political environment with lots of nepotism. This allowed many undeserving and incapable people to become management.

-True competence and hard work was noticed by managers, but rarely actually rewarded. Only numbers were considered important, and these metrics were easy to manipulate if the employees lacked integrity. If you wanted to succeed, you had to be prepared to cheat in one way or another.

-Complete lack of mobility between departments. Many employees joined the company because they were told that it was possible to transition to analyst work. When they became eligible to move departments, they were mysteriously kept in customer service (even if they worked very hard and networked well in order to be able to leave).

-Constant changes that made your job more difficult without any additional pay or thanks. This was a never ending flow of additional responsibilities handed to us.

Title: Wonderful opportunity, that opened my eyes to the world that we live in.

Title: ﻿Best company in the finance industry
View8: Just work here its the best
View10: Awesome everything Great benefits Great people Great wlb

Title: Great Place to work
View8: Fidelity does a good job of taking care of its employees. They offer great benefits and a good amount of flexibility.
View10: You are not expected to take lunch breaks. You are encouraged to work through your lunch breaks as well as arrive 30-45 minutes before your scheduled start time.

Title: Bias work environment
View8: Amazing insurance and time off benefits , managers are great to work with, employees are nice and friendly
View10: My biggest con is around covid and others may see it as a plus. However, “equal opportunity employer” is not true. If you’re vaccinated, you get extra time off the phones, free lunches in the office, development opportunities not given to those not allowed to go into the office. Whether you have medical reasons or not to not get the vaccine. It doesn’t matter to them, you will be treated less than equal which does impact career development because you don’t have the same opportunities given to those who are vaccinated.

Title: Enjoyed my 21 years, left at the right time.
View8: Good Technology and tools, Brand Name. Good benefits.
View10: Behind the curve at times with products offerings. Hiring based on diversity, not quality of applicant.

Title: Better than the service industry, but still service
View8: Lots of assistance offered to get you licensed (SIE, series 7, series 63). Inclusive culture is pushed (don't expect everyone to be that way, but at least they try to make it welcoming). Better than minimum wage. Opportunities for growth.
View10: UNDERPAID! This role requires you to live within 100 miles of Fidelity, yet they do not pay enough for a person to afford to actually live by themselves near Fidelity which is absolutely shameful. It is like being in a minimum wage job except with better pay (though, like I said, still underpaid). You get limited breaks, you are expected to clock in ten minutes early each day, it can be difficult to use your PTO. The customer's rate us on a 7 point scale, but the only acceptable score is 7 points. If you get rated a 6, that is considered failing. This role is very challenging and directly customer facing. There is a lot of pressure because you are dealing with customer's money. Fidelity throws you right into it, I did not feel ready to be moving money for customer's on my own but you just gotta do it. It is great that they sponsor you through the licensing process, but it is really easy to get burned out by their pace. Then, if you fail, prepare to be "let go." It is a FINRA rule that licensed employees cannot work from home full time without an exception process that Fidelity is not interested in participating in (it would require them to inspect your home office so I can't blame them for not wanting to do that). We can WFH right now, but will be forced to go in at least part time once it is deemed safe. Fidelity is really pushing for people to return to the office, lots of pressure to participate in "connect weeks" which is where you volunteer to go back to the office. They send you a lot of free stuff but most of it is junk. Like cheapy backpacks/mugs/merch you didn't ask for. I am putting this as a con because even though it is nice to receive free things and in the moment it gets you feeling part of the group, this practice has to stop. It is not good for the planet to keep producing useless junk.

There's still a lot of legacy technology and many platforms where release cadence is too slow to be compatible with agile methodology. There are a lot of annual required trainings that are not relevant to my day-to-day job.

Title: Sane, humane, a little slow

View10: Most of the company adjusts slowly to change. If you’ve got an “I want to see my work have impact right away” mind, you may be dismayed. But the caution, overall, is prudent and reflects conscious deliberation. If you can work at enterprise speed, it’s a good place, but you’ll lose your mind if you’re a sprinter.

I started in Customer service, and that first year was definitely the hardest. I knew nothing and felt incompetent. After a year, once you begin to build your knowledge base, you can actually have meaningful conversations so I'd say stick with it. Entry level jobs usually feel exhausting and difficult. Progress can sometimes feel slow, but I've never been in a role longer than a year and a half.

Title: The Green Machine

Plenty of great people and some pretty awesome financial industry leaders. It's a privately owned company so if they want to pursue something they don't have to get the stock holder's buy in and they allow the employees to provide input on a lot of the process and employee engagement improvements that are currently in place. Overall it's a very dynamic culture constantly changing.

Title: Great Company for the Ambitious and Energetic
View8:
Lots of pros! The pay, the perks, and the people are all great. Fidelity has tried really hard to support employees during COVID, through extra paid leave specifically coronavirus-related, counselor-finding services, fun activities and food provided for people who are willing to come back into the office part time during virus lulls.

Fidelity is also working hard on diversity-and-inclusion, and on making sure employees' voices are heard from the ground up. The company supports outside volunteer efforts and onsite environmental initiatives. You can feel good about working for a company that wants to do good, not just do well.
View10:
Most people are hired into Fidelity at this position. It's a pretty rigorous process, from submitting the application through multiple interviews. Once you're hired, there are two potential hurdles: first in learning the job then in doing the job.

Oh, the learning process! Even entirely online as it has been since the pandemic, it's kind of fun. There are get-to-know-you activities with your newbie group. But there is also a LOT of information to absorb, and it doesn't let up for months. First you learn the Fidelity systems, then you go through licensing training. You must pass the licensing exams to advance within the company. From hire, this all could take 4-6 months. Yes, they pay you the whole time. Once you're licensed, you alternate more Fidelity-specific classes with actual customer support for a few more months before you settle into full time on the phones. After a few more months of that, you may start applying within the company for new skills and new roles, your options being more self-directed.

So, the cons: the pace of learning is set to warp speed, be prepared! Realize that while you're learning you cost the company quite a bit. It's a lot of stress, but they'll want to push you as fast as they can get you to go. And once you're on the job, well, it depends. Some people like inbound phone customer service, or at least don't mind it. Fidelity customers are usually quite pleasant really. But especially in the busy months, from maybe November through tax season, they can spend more time on hold than they like, which makes them cranky. There will be constant pressure from Fidelity for you to make each call as brief as possible: they will measure both your customer satisfaction stats AND your calls per hour. It can be hard to balance the one against the other. And, this is the job: call after call after call. There are breaks, of course, from weekly team meetings to personal lunch and break time to refresher education. If you can continue in the inbound phones roles long enough, you can eventually get promoted out of it if you choose: perhaps 1-5 years, generally?

Title: Overall Excellent Company
View8:
Job security, Work-Life Balance, Great Benefits, From my experience excellent managers that work with you and do not add unnecessary stress

For many roles, you will have great job security and be extremely well-compensated compared to other companies in the industry doing the same role.

I will say that they do have a vested interest in taking care of their associates and I do feel more valued than I would in other big-name companies.
View10:
-Does not sponsor you for licensing unless you are in a role that requires it.

Overall most of the cons can be applied to any big corporate organization.

-Job growth and ability to be promoted within is definitely there, but I have seen some people become stuck in their roles if they stay too long or do not develop skills to move onto the next position. 
- In addition, moving up to management can take quite a while. I have seen it happen within the company, but a large number (especially an overwhelming number of upper-level management) either left the company and came back or were recruited externally. However, this is something that can be seen in almost any company you go to. 

- From the above my experience with management has been great, but I know on some high-intensity teams (such as sales or fund management) can have more stressful managers, but I have not heard anything terrible to note.
-Career center is just incapable

Title: It’s a marathon from sign on to sign off

It’s a marathon! From when you sign on to when you sign off it’s call after call after call… and they monitor you on everything. 

To give you an idea on the difficulty of the job. A new higher class might consist of 20 people. By the time you factor in getting licensed, trained, and then on the phones and go out one year… the quit out rate will have been 75% that’s 3 quarters of a class. 
It’s a tough job and for those who apply and can make it good for you. I lasted five years and left once I was fully vested.

View8:
Forward-thinking leadership at the helm with Abby and her team. 
Client focus on all efforts, no matter the business unit.
A desire to do more and be more as a firm when looking at the employee experience
View10:
As with any company, not all leaders represent the firm's commitment to people and their development. It's limited, but it's there. 
Too many silos when it comes to career growth, making it difficult to move across business units without taking a step back.

Title: Tech divisions lag the market in tooling, processes, comp, management, leadership, dev experience.
View8: The benefits packages are fully-featured and health insurance is affordable. The best perk of Fidelity is the 7% 401k match and the 10% annual profit sharing; 17% contributions to your 401k overall each year. The work/life balance ends up being very reasonable - it would be uncommon to work a 45-hour workweek more than a few times a year. 40 hours is the very common norm.
View10:
Fidelity does not use public cloud, which has many negative side-effects; they attempt to replicate that experience with older, internal tooling which dramatically slows developer velocity. For example, engineer's ability to access compute resources is blocked by request processes. Libraries are all subject to a security review which can take a small number of weeks if requested with priority, or many weeks without. Licenses are purchased by a remote requisitions team with a similarly slow resolution timeframe. Releases are produced manually, there is no continuous deployment. 

There is no universal devops/platform team, squads maintain their own services. 
This self-sufficiency produces isolation, practically and socially; process standards and tooling varies a fair amount between them. There is no architecture team or unified technical leadership group. Each squad has their own tech lead and that's it.

Pay for engineers lags the market, targeting approximately 80-100% of the market rate. There is no option to acquire equity. "Chairman shares" are offered to top performers, but those are simply 2-year vesting cash bonus - not actual equity. Anecdotally, the very talented engineers remain due to not knowing their own market value. 

The manager-to-report ratio can vary wildly, 50+:1 in some cases, offering virtually no manager facetime or development opportunities to members of those squads. The daily routine of managers and directors is primarily comprised of liaising with customers (other business units) rather than anything related to developing their engineering teams.

Because the tech groups service internal business units, customer requirements are often poorly defined, change frequently and are conveyed verbally to product managers over calls. Oftentimes a change will be reverted due to a customer's whim, not the functionality of the feature itself.

Leadership is adamant about working from the office and will not support remote work post-covid.

Leadership has frequent messaging about undergoing an agile transformation, yet none of the shortcomings described here are eligible for reevaluation. The remaining set of factors that can be changed are virtually meaningless in impact.

Talented top-level leadership want to lead other business units which are revenue centers (all are financial business units) rather than cost centers, so the tech groups end up with a steady rotation of SVPs (the head of the tech group, equivalent to a CEO elsewhere) every 1-2 years. 

In short, the engineer experience at Fidelity is stable, yet slow, uninspiring, and poorly-compensated when compared to the broader market.

Title: Awful position with no upward career potential
View8:
Free coffee
Training program for licensing
View10: This is a call center job. They push overtime on you and ask you to work Saturdays and guilt shame you if you decline. There is absolutely no room for growth outside of the call center. My boss had worked there for 15 years and still worked in the call center. He ended up leaving the company because he'd finally given up hope of getting something better. The system is built to keep you there. I had a 1 hour interview with an internal Fidelity position outside of the call center and they told me I couldn't have an hour off of the phones, I only get my 30 minute break.

Title: Great place going through changes

Title: Good benefits and pay but micromanaged
View8: Great pay and good benefits with 18 days PTO a year and a 7% 401K match. Monday-Friday schedule that stays consistent and optional OT. Potential to advance career.
View10: Micromanaged. It is a call center so stats are everything. If you are under preforming they will watch your every call and even listen in without you knowing. Also your bonus is mainly based on customer reviews but customers will use the review to complain about plan rules that you cannot control. So you will receive a lower bonus for simply doing your job, and stating the plan rules.

Title: Unhealthy environment
View8: The people, the benefits are great
View10: The higher the leadership closest to the top, the more close minded and attached to old school culture they are, trying to force everyone into outdated thinking.  They will also lure you into new roles and lock you down without being honest about what the role really is.  You get “used” as a vessel to push upper leadership personal motivations and accolades, while slowly being quieted down and eventually silenced.  .  It’s just a bunch of senior leaders trying to outshine each other and get their name on something even if it’s not best for the employees.  Will get overwhelming associate feedback in surveys about wanting to work remote and will only tell you about the one comment from someone who wants to be in the office and then try to gaslight you into believing it’s the majority opinion.  Leadership will “threaten” that you’re luck the President is giving you any flexibility because she would prefer not to and force you to give up all of your flexibility if you don’t agree to work in the office sometimes.  Kind of like “ you’re lucky to get anything.  Don’t push your luck or she will take all your toys away.  The culture was going in an amazing direction the past couple of years.  But in a very short time it’s gone backwards and more toxic than it’s ever been.
